title: River Stort Valley Way Walk Route

images.title: Jonathan Billinger / Stort Valley Way
images.caption: Stort Valley Way — in Essex. The circular footpath passing through this point links up with the longer Lea Valley Walk at Harlow.

images.title: Nigel Cox / Lee & Stort Navigations: Moorhen Marina turning basin
images.caption: Lee & Stort Navigations in Harlow near the Harlow Town train station. The Moorhen Marina turning basin is shown in the photo. This turning basin enables long narrowboats to make the right-angled turn into and out of the marina, which is to the right, from and to the navigable River Stort.

images.title: Stephen Craven / Bridge over the Stort Navigation at Roydon
images.caption: Bridge over the Stort Navigation at Roydon. An attractive stone bridge with balustrades, its abutments prevented by concrete fenders from collision by boats.

images.title: Tom Davison / Roydon Mill
images.caption: Roydon Mill. The old water mill at Roydon has now been converted into modern apartments, and the miller's house to the left is the reception and offices of Roydon Mill Park, a caravan park and water-ski centre.

images.title: Alan Fleming / Dobb's Weir, Nazeing.
images.caption: Dobb's Weir, Nazeing. Fish & Eels pub by the canal at Dobb's Weir, Lea Valley, Nazeing & Hoddesdon area

description: A lovely riverside circular walk around Harlow, Nazeing and Roydon. The path runs along the River Stort from Roydon and then onto Harlow and Sawbridgeworth. This section involves some easy riverside walking and a series of pretty locks. The route then heads through Matching Park, Harlow Park and Latton Park before heading back to Roydon through Bumble's Green and Nazeing.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: You could make a pit stop in Harlow at the conveniently located Moorhen. The riverside pub has a nice garden area where you can sit out and enjoy views over the river. They also do good food at reasonable prices. You can find them on Burnt Mill Lane with a postcode of CM20 2QS for your sat navs. The Old Bell in Sawbridgeworth well worthy of some investigation. The historic pub is housed in a 16th Century timber-framed former coaching house. There's a charming interior with exposed beams and a fine open fireplace. Outside there's a pleasant garden area for warmer days. You can find them on Bell Street at postcode CM21 9AN for your sat navs.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: At Roydon the trail links with the Lea Valley Walk. This long distance trail will take you along the River Lea from the source at Leagrave, near Luton, to the River Thames at Limehouse Basin. The Harlow Walk uses part of the trail to explore the river and the pretty Pishiobury Park in Sawbridgeworth. The historic park includes ‘Capability’ Brown style landscape features and riverside paths.  At Hoddesdon you could take a smaller detour to visits the abundance of birdlife at the Rye Meads RSPB Nature Reserve. For more walking ideas in the area see the Essex Walks and Hertfordshire Walks pages.

display_address: Ducketts Mead, Roydon, Epping Forest, Essex, England, CM19 5EG, United Kingdom
